div.head: TO Chriſtopher Codrington, Eſq
div.p: I Muſt own the firſt and chiefeſt Advantage I propos'd to my ſelf in this Play, was, To gain the only Opportunity, perhaps I ſhall ever have, of acknowledging to the World how very much I am bound to be Yours, not only out of Gratitude but Inclination.

From hence it might be expected, according to the Courſe of Dedications, that I ſhould forget both You and my ſelf in tiring you with your own Praiſes. No, Sir, I conſider to whom I write; nor need you bluſh at what I am going to ſay, tho' I know you are more afraid of your Friends on ſuch an Occaſion as this, than your Enemies on any other.

Were it poſſible for me to think of but attempting your Character, I ſhould eſteem my ſelf very Happy, if I could reach ſo far as the Out-lines of the Original. To proceed any further, were to draw upon my ſelf a harder Task than ever any Painter yet had. 'Twere todwell upon Lights altogether without ev'n the Mixture of a Shade.

But if I had Strength to ſupport the Undertaking, I ſhould beg leave to mention your Affability of Temper, your Perfection in Learning, a Delicacy in your Thoughts, a noble Vivacity in your Expreſſions, a matchleſs Fire in your Fancy, and a great Exactneſs of Judgment: To change the Scene your Perſonal Bravery in the Camp, your Gallantry at Court, your Zeal to ſerve your Friends, your Humanity to all the World, and your eaſie Diſpatch in Buſineſs.

Thus conſummate in Merit, no wonder your Great Maſter's Favor ſhould ſhine upon you with ſuch Diſtinction as to ſend ſo Gallant a Son to ſucceed ſo Renown'd a Father in his Commands and Governments Abroad.
Permit me, Sir, on this occaſion to wiſh you a Proſperous Voyage, and all the Happineſs that ever Man enjoy'd
I cannot end better than with ſuch a Wiſh; nor can it be ſent to you with greater Fervency by any one, than

closer.signed: Your much Oblig'd, Humble Servant, F. M.

lg.l: AS Orange-Plants that by the Gard'ner's Care
T' rive by degrees, and ſpread abroad in Air,
Expand their Branches, and extend their Roots,
As thro' their Veins prolifick moiſture ſhoots:
No • growing fertile gratefully produce
Bloſſoms and Fruit for their Preſerver's Ʋſe.
So the young Writer of the following Scenes,
To his good Friends, on whoſe Support he leans,
Preſents his very Bloſſom of a Play,
Which if you'l have the Patience but to ſtay,
May ripen the generous Fruit one Day.
His humble Muſe a tender Plant is found,
Which the firſt Year with Buds alone is crown'd.
But if mild Seaſons nurſe its ſpreading Root,
Succeeding years may bring forth grateful Fruit.
Would to kind Heav'n That Harveſt were in view,
For at our Lung's Expence We daily ſhew,
There ne'er was ſuch a Dearth of Wit as now.
Yet were it ſo that Plenty at this time
With her full Horn inrich'd our peaceful Clime,
Now to produce our Stores would be a Crime.
For our Wiſe Stage-Reclaimers would reſent
Th' Offence and bid us mortify in Lent.
Thus might we hope there's Colour to excuſe
This Author's firſt Attempt, and dawning Muſe.
Sooth then his Pain and make his Sentence eaſy,
Methinks in Lent ſome Charity ſhould ſeize you;
If you Judge nicely, he deſpairs to Pleaſe you.
OƲR Author thinks Himſelf Arraign'd to Day,
You are his Jury, and his Crime the Play.
Me He retains a Counſel in his Caſe,
What Fee He gave me I leave You to gueſs.
I come to plead before you vent your Spight,
And by your Verdict Fine Him the Third Night.
Firſt then as Criminals are wont, He chuſes
Out of his Jury ſuch, and ſuch refuſes.
The Critick He excepts, nor is it fit,
One ſhould be thought for t'other's Faults, a Wit.
Thoſe Ladies next, that ſhrow'd in Masks their Graces,
And dare ſhew any thing, except their Faces.
This Plot He to their Judgments won't Submit,
For They're contriving how Their own may hit,
The Singe han't half ſo many as the Pit.
And leaſt their Favours ſhould at laſt intrap him,
He'd rather have the Vizzards Hiſs, than Clap Him.
For want of Mercy Wits are baniſh'd hence,
And moſt of Thoſe who Write, for want of Senſe.
To cloſe the Rear, He challenges by Crowds
Bruſh'd Beavers, Nat'ral Bobs, and Velvet Hoods,
And all behind the Scenes, and all above theAlluding to the Upper Gallery above the Ceiling. Clouds.
To the Few left He lays This Maxim down,
That each ſhould make the Poet's Caſe his own.
Whoe're Themſelves of Ruine are afraid,
All Thoſe ſhould Him their Fellow-ſuff'rer Aid:
Souldiers Disbanded ſhould their Pity ſhew,
And India-Merchants, either Old or New.
You City-Dames, that from your Husbands fly
With borrow'd Looks to Pleaſe the Play'rs Eye,
And grace with Patch and Paint the Gallery.
When bluſh on bluſh, and Charms Inch thick you lay,
If He your Arts ſhould Damn as you his Play,
Would it not grieve you? Yet the ſame the Caſe is,
How many here are Authors of their Faces!
To the ſweet Beaux We make our next Complaint,
Both you that Ʋgly are, and you that Paint.
How, Sirs, ſhall we for what He feels prepare you?
Let's ſee—What is't would next to Fighting ſcare you?
Suppoſe you ſhould in ſome Lampoon appear,
Pſha, What is that? You've been too often there.
Were you confin'd by Surgeon or by Jayler,
Or, what is worſe Deſerted by your Taylor?
No: 'Tis the greateſt Penance we can find,
To leave you Comb'd and Powder'd to the Wind,
As you fear This, be to the Poet kind.
We hope at laſt we may good Luck divine
From thoſe Bright Stars that in the Boxes Shine.
Such Beauteous Eyes ſhould ſmiling Favours grant;
Nor Pity be the only Charm they Want.
You n'er ſhould Blame, to whom all Praiſe is Due,
Think but of Him as all Mankind of You.
Come, you muſt all, 'tis his firſt Fault forgive Him;
Or if not that, for poor Three Days Reprieve Him.

SCENE, The City of Valencia in Spain.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Don Bernardo, and Don Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: WEll, Bernardo, thou wilt never leave thy old courſes, I ſee, till Age or Diſtempers have made thee Impotent. The good old Count at home might, indeed, expect more Sobriety from the Tour thou haſt made abroad. But alas! poor Gentleman, he'l be as much deceiv'd in thy Manners, as thou art in following the wickedneſs of the Fleſh.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Prithee, Frederick, no more of this Gravity: I am not ſo keen a ſportſman as you make me. Indeed, if a very handſom Woman bolts out upon me unawares, I may, perhaps, courſe her now and then for a breathing: But I don't love beating the buſhes for game.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, I ſee, thou art incorrigible, therefore I have done. Methinks, Bernardo, the Air grows cool: Sure the night muſt be far advanc'd.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No matter; ee'n let us ramble for once, we ſhall find ſome Adventure or other that is diverting I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What, you are again at your old Trade: No, no, I'll home, I aſſure you. I have no mind to be miſtaken for another in the dark, and ſo have my Throat cut, or, if I eſcape that way, to be ſeiz'd upon by the Watch for a Night-walker, that has ſome ill deſign on foot.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You'll excuſe me then, for not going with you, ſince I have ſome Commands to obey to night, of one that expects a readier Compliance than any Grandee of Spain: 'Tis one Don Cupid, Seignor, if you have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Don Lucifer, you mean.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Call him what you will. But, Frederick, to be plain with you, the buſineſs is this; you muſt know, Sir, I have had a private Intrigue upon my hands with a very lovely Woman almoſt ever ſince we arriv'd at Valencia, and this very hour am I to meet her, by Aſſignation
in the mean time you are brawling with our old Hoſt at home, 'tis the better Engagement of the two.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Tis leſs dangerous, that's certain; beſides, you ſay your Intrigue is private.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It is ſo, indeed: But I'll tell you what I'll do for you, if I ſucceed in my Amour to night, and taſte of this Circe's Cup, I'll undertake you ſhall be made the next Swine, Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A pox of your Swine's Jeſt: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! good night Don Frederick. When I had told him of my Amour, I had no other way to be rid of him, for whatſoever he pretends, I know he's ſtanch, tho' a ſly Gameſter.

q.l: Now for the Coaſt of Love, on wings I'm born
To reach that Axis, on which all things turn.

div.head: SCENE II. Donna Eleonora's Longings.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Come, Dorila, let us take a walk before the door, this cool Evening.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll wait upon you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: I wonder Don Sebaſtian is not come yet: Sure ſomewhat of importance keeps him away, for he doth not uſe to be ſo tardy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He is a Man, Madam, and may forget that he has been kindly uſed by a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: I would not willingly believe any ſuch Ingratitude of him, becauſe I have long entertain'd an opinion of his faithfulneſs; and tho' the expectation he has given me of being his Wife after the death of his Mother (if the ſolemneſt Oaths and Proteſtations avail any thing) makes me a little uneaſie under a diſappointment: yet he has ſo much Goodneſs in his Nature, and ſuch Charms about his Perſon, that I can't ſoon give way to interpret any thing amiſs of him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And ſo had Don Philip, when you were firſt acquainted with him at Madrid. He had ſuch another Art of Charming too, that he ſoon gain'd a paſſage into your yielding heart, and when he had made the Conqueſt, left and deſpis'd you.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: And now he ſhall pay for his Villany; for know, Dorila, that he no ſooner left me to night, but I ſent ſome Ruffians after him to diſpatch him, leſt he ſhould hinder my deſign upon Sabaſtian, as well as to puniſh him for his Ingratitude. I wonder he could have the Impudence to inquire me out here, after the Contempt he us'd me with at Madrid. How do I long to hear the Fact is committed!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For my part I can't pity him.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Pity him, no; but I'll be reveng'd on him, Wench. He goes to Hell this night: There let him ſcorn a poor deluded Maid, that ſacrific'd her Honour to oblige him; truſted to all his flattering promiſes, and ſaw her ſelf forſaken, blaſted, ruin'd. O Woman! Woman! How eager haſt thou always been to know what brings ruin as ſoon as known! Couldſt thou but ſpare thy Curioſity, and give no Ear to the alluring Tongues of Men, how might'ſt thou live in Triumph, and ſee proud Man beneath thee!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But, Madam, you'd ſoon have the World diſpeopled at this rate.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Were it a drowning a ſecond time, 'twere no matter. 'Tis a vile World that is not worth keeping above Water. What is there to be found in it, but ſpecious promiſes and certain falſhood. Two ſuch Contagions, like North-Eaſt Winds in the Spring, are enough to blaſt Mankind, as thoſe do the Fruits of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, poor World, what a condition art thou in!

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Never in a worſe: But however, my meaning at firſt was, that I would have our Sex hold out, till they could obtain Men by Lawful means; but even then, how much diſcontent doth often follow!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why there's the buſineſs: You would deprive poor Women of their pleaſure every way. Come, come, Madam, Venus has been more indulgent to you, than you imagine, for, tho' one Lover has forſaken you, yet, thanks to fortune, you have found a Friend here that may hereafter be your Husband. Or, if you miſtruſt him there's the handſom ſtranger Don Bernardo, who has made ſome Addreſſes of Love to you.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: 'Dslife, Dorila, he was to be here to night, this very hour, by appointment, when I did not think of Sebaſtian's coming. As I live I had quite forgot it. Dorila, come, let us go and contrive ſome way to avoid meeting both.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, this it is, not to Communicate your Affairs to me. I hope by this time you ſee how neceſſary a Confidente is in your Affairs; you may have undone your ſelf now, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Come, for Venus ſake, let us go. Hark! ſome body's coming
Ha! Bernardo, as I live. Dorila, make haſte in, and after a little while call me, and I'll pretend 'tis my Aunt that calls, and ſo get away; for I wou'd not be obſerv'd to ſhun him neither.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By your leave, Ladies, I hope to find an Acquaintance here. Nay, never ſtrive to conceal your ſelf, Madam. Could the fair Eleonora think to be ſo diſguis'd, that a Lover ſhould not be able to diſtinguiſh her?

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: I might have expected ſome aſſiſtance from the darkneſs of the night, if I had not been inclin'd to diſcloſe my ſelf to you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Were the night much darker than it is, and you had kept back the goodneſs you ſhew me, yet thoſe Eyes would have diſperſed the darkneſs, and left me certain of my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: You are skill'd in Complements, I ſee; but let me intreat you to ſpeak lower, for my Aunt is yet awake, and is apt to hear the leaſt noiſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Let us walk further off then, that it mayn't be in her power either to hear us, or ſee us.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: O no, not for the World: If I ſhould not be within call, ſhe'd certainly riſe, and ſuſpect I was away upon ſome bad account. 'Twould ruin me, Sir, for ſhe's very paſſionate, and would ſurely make another Will, and give away Forty Thouſand Crowns from me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! Forty Thouſand Crowns: Can it be true?
But, Madam, when will you grant ſome pity to a Man that ſo infinitely adores you? Were we not by Appointment to meet to night?

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Are we not met, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But not as I cou'd wiſh: I would convince you of my unſpeakable Affection.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: O, Sir, then you and I muſt meet no more. Is it poſſible you ſhould entertain any ſuch unlawful hopes?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, ſhe'd hook me into Marriage!

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: Pray let me go: My Aunt calls within, and I ſhall be undone for ſtaying.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A pox of this Aunt for me.
Madam, give me leave to aſſure you, that I have no ill deſign: All that I intended was to give you moſt undeniable proofs of my Love. I intreat you to believe my ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: You talk'd juſt now at ſuch a mad rate, that 'twill be ſome difficulty to retrieve the good opinion I had of you.
O I ſhall be ruin'd, if I ſtay longer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: When ſhall I have an opportunity to bring you to a better underſtanding?

sp.speaker: Eleon.
sp.p: O never, never. You ſha'n't catch me here again to morrow night, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A Pox of all Aunts, I ſay: You ſha'n't catch me here again to morrow night I warrant you. A good direction however for to morrow; but what have I to do with to morrow? I may be leſs inclin'd for a Woman then, and leſs at leiſure. A Curſe on this Accident! Well, I'll take t'other walk, and if the Stars decree me no Adventure to night, I'll e'en home, and take Counſel of my Pillow about this laſt Affair.

div.stage: Enter Don Sebaſtian muffled in his Cloak.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Let me ſee; this muſt be the Houſe. Well, this Love has a ſtrange power: 'Tis ſo diffus'd thro' the Compoſition of Man, that all his other Faculties are like ſo many uſeleſs Wheels, till that ſpring be put in motion. What is there agreeable in Life, without Love? That Poet had a true taſte of the World, who ſaid, Let me die, ye Powers, when I am no longer able to reliſh the Bleſſings of Love. But I amuſe my ſelf too long.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Who is't that knocks at this late hour?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: 'Tis I; good Dorila, make no noiſe, but let me in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I fly, Seignor, to obey you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I'm glad they are ſo cautions whom to admit, tho' it may be nothing but diſguiſe to cheat me, for Women have their Arts, I know.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O Seignor, we have expected you ſo long, that we began to deſpair of ſeeing you to night.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I hope I am not come too ſoon. Where's my Eleonora?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: In her Chamber, impatient for your arrival, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Did you not tell her I was at the door?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I thought 'twould be more agreeable for you to ſurpriſe her with your coming.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: You have oblig'd me. Come, let us go in.

div.head: SCENE Changes. The ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A Plague upon that Sreech-owl that call'd in my Eleonora from me: For beſides my ill fortune in loſing her, ſhe has preſag'd me no luck all this night, I am afraid. Well, if I muſt go home without any Adventure to boaſt of, or to juſtifie my abſence to Don Frederick, I muſt e'en be content to bear with his dull Encomiums on Regularity and Example; tho' he, like the reſt of the Men of Zeal for ſeverity of Manners, is better pleas'd with the formality of adviſing, than the difficulty of the practice.

div.stage: A Song without, at ſome diſtance.

l.hi: To Maids it is a Pain to Love,
They freely can their Thoughts explain,
We have got Eyes and Tongues in vain,
And Truth from us is ſin.
Men to new Joys and Conqueſts fly,
Poor we are left, if we deny,

lg.l: Then equal Laws let Cuſtom find,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By your leave, whoe'er you are, I mean to interrupt your Singing, tho' I like it well. This may prove ſome lucky check to my riſing inclination to go home. I'll follow the voice, whatever may enſue.

div.head: SCENE changes to Don Frederick's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Don Frederick and his Man Anthony.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: From Alcantara, did he ſay?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, from Alcantara, and when he knew that, I had the Honour to be your Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are pleaſant, Sirra.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I hope 'tis not an Employment above me, for the Heralds have diſtinguiſh'd us in France.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So they will a Fidler, if he has mony to purchaſe a Coat of Arms.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you don't ſpeak of that Profeſſion by way of Contempt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What doth it deſerve elſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: I am ſorry for your Judgment, for we were always eſteemed in our Country.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O, I find you were your ſelf an Inſtrument Scraper there once: But no more of this. What requeſt did this ſtranger make to you?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: That I ſhould let you know, upon your coming home, that he was very earneſt to ſpeak with you alone.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So privately: Who can it be? Come, lead me to him; I long to know who 'tis.

div.stage: A Bed-chamber. Donna Cornelia in Man's Cloaths, ſitting by a Table in a thoughtful poſture.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: What a Capricious Deity is Love, and how repugnant often to Nature it ſelf! So true are thoſe Lines of the Divine Engliſh Poet.

q.l: In Love the Victors from the Vanquiſh'd fly,
They fly that wound, and they purſue that dy.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Seignor, my Maſter, Don Frederick, if you are diſpos'd to receive his viſit, would wait on you.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: With all my heart; I ſhall eſteem his Company as a favour.
Now muſt I unfold my ſelf to him, and if he has that Generoſity the World gives him, he will both ſecure me from my Brother's indignation, and aſſiſt me towards the ſucceſs of my deſign.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sir, I was made believe upon my coming home, that you had ſome Commands for me. I ſhould be glad to have it in my power to obey a Stranger, eſpecially one whoſe Aſpect can even ſo ſoon prevail on my Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Sir, your Language and Behavour ſpeak you Generous: I did indeed make it my requeſt to your Servant, who had inform'd me of yours and Don Bernardo's Loding here, to give you private notice that a Stranger was earneſt to ſpeak with you. Be not ſurpris'd, Sir, but oblige me ſo far as to ſit down, and hear my Story.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sir, I am ready to give all attention.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I preſume, Sir, by the Deſcription you may have had of me, and the Garb you ſee me in, you take me for one of your own Sex.
Be not amaz'd, Sir, for I am but a Woman, a moſt unhappy Woman, no other than the Siſter of your Friend Don Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me, Donna Gornelia!

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: The ſame: Pray how long is it ſince you and my Brother arrived here from Italy?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: We have been in Spain about four days, and only wait for the paſſing of to morrow's Feſtival, before we go for Alcantara. 'Tis the great Feaſt of St. Jago, at whoſe Church to morrow is to be ſeen all the Magnificence of this Place.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: 'Tis poſſible then you may have ſeen Don Philip de Monaſco, in this Town.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have only heard of him, Madam, I never had the honour to know him.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
Alas, Sir, 'tis he that is the cauſe of this diſguiſe, this Journey to Valencia, and of all the misfortunes that have yet befaln me.
Not to detain you, you muſt know that Don Philip making uſe of the Acquaintance of our Friends, came frequently to our Houſe, and was always entertain'd with that welcome that was due to the Son of a Man of Quality, and a particular Friend. I muſt confeſs, that from the firſt moment I ſaw him, I had a more than ordinary Joy to think we were under the ſame Roof, and an unuſual heavineſs when he went away. How ſoon doth Love find entrance into a weak Woman's heart! I fanci'd whene'er he appear'd before me, that there was not a Man in Spain of ſuch Beauty, Grace, and Proportion; but when he ſpoke, ſure Muſick hung upon his Tongue, and all he ſaid I thought Oraculous.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, now you are far gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You'l excuſe my weakneſs, Sir. After many diſcourſes we had together full of Complaiſance and Gallantry, He at laſt made ſome advances of Love. You may imagine I was not diſpleas'd to find a mutual concern. This humour he continued for many days, and at laſt after a Thouſand Solicitations attended with Oaths and Promiſes of Marriage: I was Fool enough to yield.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Heavens! Can it be?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: To an agreement to meet him ſuch a day.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your diſcretion may be yet ſafe. But pray, Madam, why did you not give your Father notice of your mutual Inclinations, that he might have procur'd Don Philip for your Husband?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Becauſe I knew he had given his word to another Gentleman, and had commanded me to prepare to accept him for my Husband, tho' I told him I could never love him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, Madam, when the day came?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I met him at the appointed place, but had the prudence to reſolve before-hand not to yield till he ſhould actually have Married me. He uſed many importunities to perſwade me, but, I thank Heaven, I had ſo much reaſon left, as to conſider, that he who refus'd to ſend for a Prieſt, when I gave him an opportunity, by being abſent from my Father's Houſe, wou'd ſcarce agree to do it when he had once enjoy'd me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Twas wiſely reaſon'd, Madam; ſo you broke off.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: We did from what he propos'd, but not from a Contract we had made before.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! Contracted?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: A Solemn Contract had paſs'd between us.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am ſorry for't. Pray, what has induc'd you to come hither in diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
Two days after our Adventure, I was inform'd that Don Philip was privately gone to this Place, in order to take Shipping for Naples, and had carried with him a beautiful young Lady, whom he
had newly married, or deſigned to marry. This News put me into ſuch a fit of melancholy, that I could not conceal it from the Family, which was very earneſt to know the Cauſe, but in vain. After a day or two I took a reſolution to diſguiſe my ſelf, and to come directly to Valencia to find out this ungrateful Philip, who is my Husband before Heaven, tho' another has the happineſs to live with him. If I can find them, I'll either pull her by force out of his Arms, and let the World know the claim I have to him, or if he refuſes to own me for his Wife, he ſhall experience the Revenge of a Neglected Woman.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Madam, if I might adviſe you, things being not yet gone ſo far as to neceſſitate your purſuit of him at this rate, you ſhould even deſpiſe him in your turn, and make choice of another that ſhould be more worthy of your Love.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, if we could Love whom we would, your Counſel might be choſen: But Love, you know, has Fate in it, and therefore cannot be withſtood.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You may be Wedded to a falſe opinion of Love; there's no ſuch Aſtrology in the matter.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: However, 'tis impoſſible I can ever forget Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Few things are impoſſible, Madam, they only appear ſo to us for want of putting them in practice: However, let us refer this buſineſs, if you pleaſe, till the morning; you muſt needs want reſt after the fatigue of a Journey. To morrow you may Command me as far as I have any Power.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: But, Sir, I muſt intreat one Favour of you, which is, that you give my Brother no Intelligence of my being here, for I fear his Anger as much as the neglect of Philip.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhall be careful to obey your Commands. Good reſt to the fair Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Alas! I can have no reſt: This ungrateful Man will keep me for ever waking. To go to Bed is only to toſs from ſide to ſide, to be tormented with Sighs, and inflam'd with Jealouſie.

q.l: O Love, in Notion ſo tranſporting Fair,
Once Felt, what Wreks and Tortures doſt Thou bear
Between the Flames of Hope and Coldneſs of Deſpair.

div.trailer: She End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT the Second.
SCENE the Firſt: The ſtreet.
div.stage: Enter Don Bernardo, with Donna Olivia in Mans Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: THe relation you have made me, Madam, of this ungrateful Philip, as it makes me look upon you with the tendereſt Compaſſion, ſo it gives me reaſon to deteſt the Author of your misfortune. You ſay he promis'd you Marriage firſt with all the marks of ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He wiſh'd a thouſand times that Heaven might pour down Vengeance on his head, if he prov'd falſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What a Villain is he then for leaving you thus!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He is ſo, and yet I love this Villain. O! Bernardo, do but frame to your ſelf the ſofteſt delights that ever any Lov'd Woman has yet rais'd in your Soul: Fancy how tranſported you ſhould be with the full poſſeſſion of her Charms: Think what a pain 'twould be to live depriv'd of ſuch a happineſs; and then conclude what I have loſt in Philip.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Amazement! Can there be ſo much felicity in our Sex? I thought all we had on Earth was to be found in yours.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I find you think me vain, Sir, in giving ſuch a Character of a Man, with whom I have had ſome underſtanding: But 'tis my infirmity, pray paſs it by.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I am well pleas'd than any of our Sex can be ſo very acceptable. I'll recant the name of Villain I call'd him too, if 'twould oblige you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: His leaving me looks unkind enough, indeed, but could I meet him here, I ſhould not doubt the recovery of his heart, I know it was nothing but a youthful ſally to make me ſenſible of the want of his dear Company, that I might receive him at his return with more than uſual Ardour.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How ready the fond thing is to excuſe this treacherous Fellow!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But whatever be the cauſe, I muſt intreat you, ſince the Accident of my voice brought you to diſcover my paſſion, that you would give me your aſſiſtance, as ſoon as 'tis day, to find out this Rambler, if he be in Valencia; if not, O misfortune! Whither ſhall I go to ſeek him?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You may command my faithfuleſt ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Another Requeſt I have to make to you, which is, that you conceal my being here from Don Frederick's knowledge for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I ſhall obey you. You'll give me leave to wait on you to your Lodging, and, as ſoon as 'tis day, I ſhall not fail to ſend to know your Commands.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You maintain the Character the World is full of.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sure I muſt be near Don Sebaſtian's: Anthony, don't you know the Street?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: If 'twere not quite ſo dark, poſſibly I might, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: As far as I remember, we ſhould paſs by this Church.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, you were always for paſſing by the Church, I'll ſay that for you; but if you live at this rate, the Church won't paſs You by very long.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why how now, Sirra, you are Witty to night: What, you have been punning in Donna Eleonora's Kitchin, ſervile Rogue!

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, 'tis a miſtake, with your pardon; for there was Mrs. Pert, her Maid, who has ſo unreaſonable a Tongue, that ſet it once a going, 'tis a very Laram for an hour together, ſo that no body can be heard but ſhe. Will you give me leave, Sir, to tell you ſomething ſhe ſaid?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Barring all Smut, and ſo forth, which thou canſt no more forbear interlarding in thy diſcourſe, than an Old Maid when ſhe is paſt hopes of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Smut, Sir, I ſcorn your Words; I'll have you to know we Frenchmen have more good Breeding.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, your Nation has the Character for good Manners.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Ay, and for good Courage, good Politicks, and good Subjects, Begar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How do you make your Courage out, pray, my Underſtanding Valet?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Why, we always get the better of our Enemies by our Numbers, and ſo our Courage is not diſputed. Then as for Politicks, don't you know a Nation, Sir, that has had cunning enough to get a Peace concluded, when 'twas Six to four that it had been undone in another Campagne.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I'm afraid that condition regarded more than one Nation. Well, and how are you good Subjects?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: In troth, I think we are very good, eaſie Subjects, to ſuffer all to be reſtor'd in one Day that we had been getting for half an Age.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Admirable Paſquil! Well, but thou haſt rambled all this while from thy Theme: Thou art a true Frenchman in thy Tongue at leaſt, which is ever running a ſwift Courſe without any Goal before
it. I thought I was to have had a decent Account of your late Converſation.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your Pardon, with all my heart: Why, Sir, what do you think this wicked Jade told me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come, out with it.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, as ſure as you're alive, this Water-wagtail told me, that the whole buſineſs of this wicked Town was Love.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo, my little Anthony?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Nay, I knew 'twould pleaſe you, for you are ſuch a Hawk at the Sex, that the very name of an Intrigue, tho' you were to croſs the Sea for't, would be a Lure to you. But, pray, Sir, let me intreat you to ſet me a better Example, that we may both leave this pernicious way; for, to tell you the truth, I have ſo great a reſpect for you, that I can no more forbear following all your ſteps like a true Serving man, than an old Sharper can thoſe of a young Heir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Leave off your Canting, Sirra, for thou lov'ſt. Woman's fleſh as naturally as Spaniards love Conſtancy, or Engliſhmen Change.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: But, Sir, how can you ſo ſoon forget the Beautiful Cornelia? I dare ſwear ſhe's pining and languiſhing for her Contracted Husband.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let her languiſh on: A fooliſh Wench, ſhe might have had what ſhe languiſh'd for, but Vertue, forſooth, flew in her face, and made her reſolve to ſtarve her Love. Now for a Woman, commend me to Olivia, that no ſooner lov'd but nouriſh'd her deſire, leaving the dull fantaſtick notion of Fame and Honour, for the lively ſubſtantial Enjoyment of Man and Happineſs.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: And yet you could forſake her too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes, becauſe ſhe began to trouble me, like the other, with my promiſe of Marriage: They would have had me worn a very ſtrait Shooe that galls and pinches one even to Lameneſs. To marry is to open Pandora's Box, which is no ſooner done, but all kinds of miſeries flutter about your Ears.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: And have you no qualms of Conſcience for theſe things?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Not I, fool; Pleaſure is my Employment, and my Conſcience is ſubſervient to it.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruf.
sp.p: It muſt be he by what we have heard: Courage, Friends, prepare.

sp.speaker: 2 Ruf.
sp.p: I'll have his head at the firſt ſtroak, an ungrateful Villain.

div.stage: Four or five enter and come forward.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: I hear a noiſe, Sir: Let us jog on and find the Houſe, if it be poſſible.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Stay. Who's there? What's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: 1 Ruf.
sp.p: We come to ſend a Villain to the Devil.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: I am Thunderſtruck, I'm Dead; did not I tell you, Sir, that the injuries you have done to thoſe Gentlewomen would come home to you, and now you have involv'd me too?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Anthony, ſtand up cloſe to me, d'ee hear, or, by the Maſs, I'll give you into their hands, whoever they are.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will ſtand cloſe, Sir. A pox confound them for me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well, who is this Villain you talk of? If you expect to find him here, you are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruf.
sp.p: We know you are a Villain, as ſure as you are Don Philip, therefore fall on, Friends.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to defend our ſelves: Anthony, keep cloſe to me, or d'ee hear, I ſhall thruſt you before me to be firſt ſlain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Poor Anthony! how hard it is that other Mens ſins ſhould fall upon thy head!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Will you hear me? I am not the Man you take me for: I am a ſtranger here.

sp.speaker: 2 Ruf.
sp.p: No, no; fall on, fall on.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruf.
sp.p: Courage, Lads, remember the Reward: 'Tis to kill a Villain, ſo 'tis no murder.

sp.speaker: 2 Ruf.
sp.p: If he were an honeſt Man 'twere all one to me. What, every Man muſt live in his way.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O bloody-minded Rogues! I wiſh I do not ſwoon before the fight begins.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Since no intreaties will prevail, come on: I ſhall ſend ſome of you, blood hounds, to Hell, before you murder me, I ſhall.
sp.stage: Don Bernardo by the claſhing of Swords is brought that way, and joyns with Philip.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Take Courage, Sir; you have one by your ſide that would ſtand by you, were the number of your Adverſaries double.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Whoe'er you are, you are very generous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, then I'll e'en ſteal away, and ſave my ſelf.
sp.stage: They fight ſtill, at laſt the noiſe of the Watch makes the Ruffians retire.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruf.
sp.p: The Watch! The Watch! Let us ſhift for our ſelves!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, I am extreamly in your debt for your timely aſſiſtance and ſhould be glad to know of whom I have receiv'd ſo important a ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I have done no more, Sir, than the duty of a Gentleman oblig'd me to; you were over-power'd by Numbers, and Humanity forc'd me to take your part. My name is of little moment to you, ſince I am a ſtranger in this Place.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You are my preſerver, however: Let me intreat you then to be ſeen to morrow. The Watch, I find, is alarm'd, and will be every where; Their rudeneſs is to be avoided.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You may Command me any where in the morning.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let it be then near the great Church, at Ten.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You'l pleaſe to give me Your name.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me, Sir, for ſome private reaſons, but if you'll pleaſe to wear this Sword, whoſe Hilt is of a remarkable Frame, and of no ordinary Value, I ſhall have the pleaſure of knowing you again at the time and place.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The ſatisfaction you promiſe me, makes me willing to exchange Swords, which I ſhould otherwiſe be aſham'd to do, ſince mine is of no value.
sp.stage: Watch without, cry, This way, this way.
sp.p: Good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Fortune ever attend you. Anthony: Where the Devil is he? Sure he is not dropt in the Fray: I ne'er miſs'd him till now; but let him be where he will I muſt avoid this Watch.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Here this way they went. Let's after them.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Follow, follow!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I can go no way but theſe damn'd Conſtables, and their guard of Watchmen are upon the hunt. How to eſcape them, I don't well know.
sp.stage: A noiſe without, This way, this way.
sp.p: The dogs are upon full ſcent, and I ſhall be finely mumbled if I ſtay here. Ha! a door open; nay, then there needs no pauſing for a reſolution what to do.
sp.stage: Goes in, and ſhuts the door faſt.

div.stage: Enter Conſtable and Watchmen, with 1ſt. Anthony.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: Here's one of the Rogues.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Come, bring him before our Prince of Darkneſs here, to be examin'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Prince of Darkneſs, hum! then am I in Hell it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Come, Sir, in the firſt place, Who are you, that has had the Impudence to diſturb the King's Peace, and the Quiet of our Government?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, the King's Peace, and your Government put together, have made me forget my ſelf in the Wonder.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Sir, I'll have you to know, I am the King's Image, and Viceroy of his Nocturnal hours in Valencia.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I beg your pardon now you have explain'd your ſelf, and to give you no further trouble, my name is honeſt Anthony.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Honeſt Anthony! here's a Rogue now, when, as I am an Aſſiſtant to his Majeſty's Image here, I found him cram'd in a Cellar Window.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis very ſuſpitions, let me tell you, Friends; for if he had not been upon ſome Wicked Deſign he would ne'er have hid himſelf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Plain, plain: Some Houſe-breaker.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: I warrant he's a Cendary in his heart, and came to ſet fire to the City.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Like enough, truly, for tho' we have a Peace d'ee ſee, we ought to be upon our guard; elſe what our Enemies could not bring to paſs by the Sword, they may try to do by Fire.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Pauvre Antoine!

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: D'ee hear, Mr. Conſtable, what Gibberiſh the Rogue ſpeaks: I warrant that's Treaſon, if we knew what 'twas. I ſay, let him be hang'd without any more a-doe.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: What, d'ee talk of hanging only: I humbly move, Mr. Conſtable, that he may be firſt hang'd and then drown'd.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nay, hold a little, my hearts of Steel: The Law takes notice of Life and Death, d'ee ſee. Let us proceed regular, d'ee mind. If upon further Examination, that is — we find him a Vagabond —That is to ſay—a Fellow, that—you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Ay, ay: One that can't anſwer for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ay, that's it, Tom, the very thing I would have ſaid: But as I was ſaying, if he can give no 'count of himſelf, that is—We'll put him in the Stocks till morning, d'ee mind, and then carry him before a Magiſtrate. This is a Conſtable's duty.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis ſo, Mr. Conſtable: I had forgot my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Well, Friend, ſince the Queſtion of Who are you is anſwer'd, the next is always, What are you?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, what are you? ha!

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, I am a ſtranger here, I muſt own. But—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: He has Condemn'd himſelf: A miſchievous Rogue, I warrant him. What ſay you, Gentlemen, ſhall we proceed to Sentence?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, ay, to Sentence, to Sentence.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: And then to Execution with him.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Nay, good Gentlemen, do but hear me: I am not—

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Stop his mouth for him; he's Convicted.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Ay, ay; 'tis not the cuſtom for a Criminal to ſpeak after Conviction. Be ſilent, you had beſt, and harken to your Sentence.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Well then, ſince we have, upon a full Hearing and a clear Evidence, found him to be a Rogue, the next thing is, to proceed to Sentence, which I pronounce thus. You are, Sirra, to ſit in the Stocks till morning, and then you muſt expect to go to Priſon, and from thence to be hang'd at leaſt, if not impal'd alive.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Come, away with him; away with him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Away! Away!

div.stage: Scene changes to Dan Frederick's Lodgings. Enter Don Frederick alone, with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
What, in the name of wonder, ail'ſt thou, Frederick, that thou canſt not go to ſleep? Is it not the time when Men forget their daily cares, and lay themſelves to reſt? All are at Peace within theſe
Walls, but Thou. As I paſs'd by Cornelia's Room, methought I could have crav'd admittance there, but that I recollected ſhe was tir'd with her Journey, and 'twould be barbarous to wake her. Ha! wake her! What pretence have I to wake her? Wake whom, Cornelia, for what? Have a care, Frederick, this Woman runs in thy head ſo much, that there is no reaſon either in thy actions, or thy talk. Why then I am in Love, it ſeems: Speed you, Sir. In Love! with whom? Why, Cornelia. There 'tis again: With one, that has left a kind Father, to run a gadding after an Ungrateful Lover. O well plac'd Affection!

q.l: If I muſt feel your power, cruel Cupid,
Why have you made me fix my thoughts on one
From whom I can expect no kind return?
But the blind Boy delights in Tyranny.

sp.p: Well, ſince I can't ſleep, I'll e'en walk out, and try if I can meet Don Bernardo.
sp.stage: Goes to the door, and calls Anthony.
sp.p:
How faſt the Raſcal is! Stretch'd upon the Floor he ſleeps as hea •••
ly as if he had taken Opium. Thou haſt no cares to keep thee waking, much happier than thy Maſter. Why Anthony?
Make no noiſe, but come hither.

div.stage: Enter 2 Anthony, yawning, and rubbing his Eyes.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: What would your Worſhip have, Sir? you wak'd me out of the moſt extraordinary Dream.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What was your Dream, you ſleepy ſot? here, take the Candle.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, methought the World was turn'd Topſie-turvy; Integrity was come in faſhion at Court, and Modeſty the road to Preferment there. Great Miniſters no longer wrack'd Attendance, and advanc'd Men of Worth, without putting them to the bluſh to ask. Lawyers forbore taking Fees on both ſides, and Phyſicians after their Patients were dead. The Clergy were in eſteem for not going from their Text, and Tradeſmen were grown Conſcientions. Right and Wrong were no more the Subjects of Diſpute, and Men of Sence valu'd Things more than Words. Envy and Oſtentation were no longer known among Wits and Criticks, nor Controverſies among Divines.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why, this was a Golden Age.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, would it were more than a Dream. But to purſue it, methought all Women were grown Vertuous; Balls and Maſquerades were quite laid aſide; Vails and Vizards were out of doors, they were not ſuffer'd ev'n at the Playhouſes; City Ladies no longer affected to out-ſhine Quality, nor Court Lords joynd iſſue with the City. In a Word, Sir, Honeſty, Diſcretion and good Breeding went hand in hand together.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But how will you Interpret this Dream?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if once you come to that, I know what 'twill come to—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Ev'n nothing, Sir; for the rule of interpreting dreams is by their contraries.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Therefore you're out, for if you perſue that rule, you have the very World we live in. But no more; I have a mind to walk out to try if I can meet Don Bernardo. Make no anſwer, but follow me.

div.head: SCENE the Street.
div.stage: Enter Don Philip, with two of Don Sebaſtian's Servants, with Lanthorns

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hold, let me ſee; It muſt be hereabouts that I was ſet upon by Ruffians, and reliev'd by a ſtrange Gentleman, when I miſs'd my Man Anthony. Pray let us look about for him: 'Tis poſſible he may have fain in the Encounter; if he did, he ſhall have a decent Funeral for the Service he has done me. Yet I would not loſe the Rogue neither, if I could help it, becauſe he us'd to divert me often with his Country raillery.
sp.stage: The Servants are looking about all this time.
sp.p: You ſay Don Sebaſtian is not at home to night.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: No, Seignor, begs you would excuſe him till morning.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: With all my heart.
sp.stage: Enter Don Frederick, and his Man.
sp.p: Ha! who are theſe that come this way? One of your Lights, that I may view them.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Good Evening, Seignor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Seignor, the like to you.
sp.stage: Fred. paſſes by, and his Man comes after.
sp.p: Ha! is not that Anthony?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: As I live, Anthony riſen from the dead.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Sirs, my name is Anthony, but I was never dead yet, I thank Heaven: If you will not believe me, my Maſter, who is gone before, will confirm, that I have been alive at leaſt theſe two years.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How, Slave! have you forſaken me then, and, not only ſo ſoon found another Maſter, but do you banter me too?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! what mean you, Friends? Forſaken whom? Whom has he banter'd? Pray give him leave to do his duty in following me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hey day! Pray do you give your opinions of him?
Is not this Anthony, that came with me to your Maſter's Houſe; and has been with me ever ſince, till within this half hour?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Why, what a Rogue are you, Anthony, to deny your ſelf to your Maſter?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: 'Tis either Anthony, or the Devil in his ſhape, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now, Sir, are you convinc'd yet?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Of your miſtake, I am ſure you are all bewitch'd to talk thus. I tell you, he has liv'd with me theſe two years in Italy, and we are newly arriv'd here from thence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, ſince you are ſo poſitive, and he's ſuch a Raſcal to deny me, I have done: You ſhall keep your Man, and much good may he do you; only ſpare me one word, which is this, 'tis very certain, that one and the ſelf-ſame Perſon, could not have liv'd with me in Spain, and with you in Italy, at the ſame time; tho' one of our Modern Virtuoſi has boldly undertaken to prove the poſſibility of ſuch a thing. But, Sir, 'tis as certain, that this very individual Fellow that you have taken into your Service, has been my Man every day for theſe ſix months, or it muſt be the Devil in his Perſon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sir, we are all ſubject to be deceiv'd; 'tis likely your Man might bear ſome reſemblance to him; that you are miſtaken in him, I'll wager my Eſtate; for, I repeat it to you again, he has liv'd with me theſe two years.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I ſhould be ſorry to offend you, or any Genleman, but, upon my honeſt Word, Sir, I never ſaw your Face before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Be damn'd, Sir. Come, let us go: I'm weary of this illuſion.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, pray let us go, for fear it ſhould be the Devil in good earneſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Speed you, Sir, with your new ſervant.

div.stage: Exeunt Don Philip and Don Sebaſtian's Men.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What a Whimſical Adventure have I met with? I wonder what time of the Moon 'tis? Sure theſe Men have loſt their Wits, they could ne'er have been ſo miſtaken elſe. Well, the morning may diſcover more of this. I'll take t'other walk, and ſee what I can meet with next.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I Believe I ſurpris'd you, but I had no other way to eſcape the rude Watch, neither did I know whoſe door it was I ſo ſeaſonably found open, tho' at an unſeaſonable hour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Lady was horribly frightned, when I told her firſt of it, but when ſhe was a little recover'd, ſhe call'd me to her Bedſide, and whiſp'ring, leaſt her Aunt, whom ſhe lay with, ſhould hear her, charg'd me to beg your Excuſe for her not ſeeing you; and that you might be convinc'd, 'twas nothing but the fear of her Aunt, if ſhe ſhould attempt to riſe, that hindred it: She commanded me to preſent you with this Ring, as a Teſtimony of her Favour.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay then, Mrs. Dorila, you muſt oblige me ſo far as to accept of this.

Pray tell your Lady, I'll ever wear it for her ſake, and to morrow I hope to acknowledge to her in Perſon, this generous Favour. In the mean time, pray do you make my Excuſe to her for this Accident, and the diſturbance I have unhappily caus'd her. Good morrow, Mrs. Dorila.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I ſhall obey your Commands, Seignor.

I am glad he's gone, for if Don Sebaſtian and he ſhould have met here, there would have been fine Work. Now doth this Amoriſt believe he has receiv'd a ſignal favour from his Miſtreſs, when in truth ſhe knows nothing of the matter. The Ring's but a Trifle, and was given her formerly by Don Philip, and ſhe gave it me: However, as ſoon as her Lover Sebaſtian goes, I muſt acquaint her with it to prepare her againſt the next time ſhe ſees Bernardo. Well, let the Men ſay what they will, our Wits are quickeſt, that's certain.

div.head: SCENE the Street.
div.stage: Don Philip's man Anthony in the Stocks.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p:
Poor Anthony! This Puniſhment is certainly a Judgment upon thee for ſerving ſo debauch'd a Maſter. Well, Don Philip,
you have been met with too: If you are ſlain by thoſe Ruffians I left you engaged with, why then my Cowardice has got the advantage of your Courage. If you have eſcap'd them, I hope the danger will be a warming for you to reform your Life. O my Legs, my Legs! Now am I juſt for all the World as if I were Married. Ha! who comes here?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis yet too early to go home for one of my wakeful Conſtitution. I'll e'en ſaunter about, and if nothing happens worthy my humble attention here below, I'll erect my face, and pleaſe my ſelf with the obſervation of the growing day: Nor is't an unprofitable Amuſement to view the ſeparation of Light and Darkneſs, to ſee day and night ſtruggle for Empire. For by this reflection may one learn the nature of humane paſſions, that at firſt make wild contention with our Reaſon, which riſing by degrees like the Lights force, diſperſes all their gloom, and brings forth Day to the Underſtanding.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: This muſt be ſome Philoſopher, or Star-gazer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! One ſo near me. Who are you, ſpeak?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: No Dancing-maſter—for I want Legs.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sure 'tis Anthony's voice.
Why, how now, Anthony, how came you here, and in this humility?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Sir, if you'll vouchſafe to let me know how you came ſo well acquainted with me, I'll ſoon anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What, is your Preferment ſo great, that you have forgot me? I could hardly have expected to have found the Quality of a Great Man in the Stocks.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: You are a very pleaſant Gentleman. But, Sir, 'tis an unſeaſonable time for mirth; and take this from me, I never ſaw you in my Life before.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sure he's diſtracted. Pray, who are you, Friend?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: I am a Native of that Country that you ſcorn, tho' it has made you tremble. I have the honour to be a Subject of the Grand Monarque, who, in time of War, knew how to turn a Skirmiſh into a great Fight; the reduction of a Village into that of an invincible Caſtle, and the loſs of a Battle into an abſolute Victory, and ſung Te Deum for them all.
sp.stage: All this in a big voice.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A very Politick Perſon! And where do you live, my notable States-man?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: In the Stocks.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Good. But where, before you were thus exalted?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: I ſerv'd a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: All this agrees mighty well. Pray, what's his name?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Now his fit returns; poor fellow.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Was it not enough I told you that I ſerv'd a Spaniard. By all my wrongs 'twas too much; 'twas adding to the diſgrace I am under. Thoſe of our Country ſhould Command, not Serve; at leaſt not ſerve a thing ſo ſtupid as a Spaniard: One that prefers a lazy Luxury before an active Frugality, and would not loſe a formal Ceremony, or part with an Inch of his Grandeur to ſave his Country from Ruin.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This is notorious Truth, tho it come from the mouth of a Madman. Farewel, Anthony. I'll ſend you relief in the morning.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: You'l do more than I expect then.

Who ſhould this Man be? I never ſaw him in my Life before, and yet he will needs be acquainted with me. Well, if he ſhould ſend to releaſe me, according to his promiſe, I ſhall be oblig'd to him, that's certain. So I were out of this nooſe, I ſhould not care if I were to be converted into a Spaniard, or an Engliſhman, tho they are as much extreams as Fire and Water: For as one by his Violence always ſhoots beyond the Mark, ſo the other by his Lazineſs ever falls ſhort of his Diſtance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! I don't like theſe Fellows. ſtill as I go on, they follow me. I turn'd down this Street on purpoſe to avoid them, and yet they are here. I'll make what haſt I can homewards, or try to loſe them by the way.

sp.speaker: 1 R.
sp.p: It muſt be Don Philip by the glittering of his Sword-hilt. I took particular notice of that before.

sp.speaker: 2. R.
sp.p: So did I. Sure it muſt be ſet with Diamonds.

sp.speaker: 1. R.
sp.p: So much the better ſtill, Boys, 'tis lucky we have found him again. Come, we may diſpatch him yet.

sp.speaker: 2. R.
sp.p: Away, away. We loſe time.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay, if you follow me ſtill, I may well ſuſpect your deſign. So, I am met with for my Curioſity. But hold, ſure I am come round again to Eleonora's. By my ſurprize I am. I'll ſtrive to get in here before they come up to me. St. Eleonora, Dorila, Hem.

div.stage: Eleonora in her Nightgown at the Window.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Who calls Eleonora at this early hour?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Bernardo. For Heavens ſake, dear Creature, let me in this moment, for I am purſu'd by Ruffians. Uſe no delay or objection, for if you do I am a Dead Man.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pho, this is one of the Artifices of you young Fellows, to ſeduce a tender Maid. You muſt excuſe me, Seignor. Beſides, if I had an inclination, my Aunt is yet ſtirring, and it concerns my Honour, and Well-being with her not to admit you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Come you are deſign'd to preſerve me, for let me go which way I will to night, ſtill I meet with your Houſe. 'Twill be now the ſecond time my ſhelter this night from imminent Danger.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir! you talk ſtrangely. My doors are never open'd at late hours to any one.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Madam, what do you mean? the Ring, the Ring.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What of a Ring? I don't know your ſign, Sir, 'Tis plain you are miſtaken in the Houſe, therefore Adieu.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Miſtaken in the Houſe, that's impoſſible. Neither can I be in that deluding Voice. Is it not cruel to trifle with me thus at ſuch a time? Alas! ſhe's gone indeed. Diſcourteous Eleonora! Well, if they do aſſault me, I muſt e'en defend my ſelf as well as I can.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruf.
sp.p: There he is like a Rat caught in a Trap. He can retire no further.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: But hold, hold. Let us be ſure 'tis he before we ſend him to Lucifer's Dominions. I would not kill a wrong man neither.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruf.
sp.p: What d'ee talk of a wrong man? don't you ſee how his Sword glitters? it muſt be he by that.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: Ay, but if I thought he were not the right-man I would not be concern'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruf.
sp.p: Why 'tis he, what a pox d'ee ail? I'll ſwear it upon any Maſs-book in Spain. What do you flinch now? you have forgot the Reward ſure.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: The reward, let me ſee. Maſs, and ſo I had. A hundred Crowns, Maſs, 'tis enough to ſlay an Emperor. Come, he dies.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruf.
sp.p: Come on then, let us move towards him.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it muſt be he: 'Tis the very Sword he had before.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What's your deſign, Friends, in following me thus?

sp.speaker: 1. Ruf.
sp.p: Nay, you are miſtaken, we are none of your friends, and for our deſign, that you may gueſs at by your own Villanys.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Villanys? you amaze me. I am a Stranger here, and have done wrong to none.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: We'll ſoon try if we are miſtaken. Know we are reſolute, and will trifle no longer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay, if you are ſo bent to murder me, I'll ſell my Life as dear as I can.

div.p: The noiſe of Swords brings Don Frederick that way.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! three againſt one, Cowardly Villains! 'tis Bernardo, as I live.
Courage, my Friend.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You were never more wellcome.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: Nay, if you are there abouts, I'll wait here for the Iſſue of the Engagement.

sp.speaker: Ber
sp.p: Dogs, Villains.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Blood-ſucking Sons of Whores.

div.stage: The 2. Ruffian falls, the other two run away.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So, here's one of them rewarded.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: O ſpare my Life, and I'll confeſs all.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! not dead: then we may learn this Myſtery.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: O Seignor, is not your name Don Philip de Monaſco?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No, you are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I was in ſome doubt of it before, but my Companions ſaid they knew you by the glittering of your Sword.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! Don Philip, by the glittering of my Sword! but ſuppoſe it had been Philip, how were you induced to commit violence upon him.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruf.
sp.p: We were hired to it by one Donna Eleonora that lives hard by.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: My barbarous Miſtreſs, as I live!
Well, what was it for, come, out with all, or the Watch ſhall have you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: She only told us he had wrong'd her ſo heinouſly, that it was not to be forgiven, and we were to have a hundred Crowns for our Reward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, you may go. But, do you hear, if you are wiſe, This mercy that I ſhew to you, will be a means to make you change your Life.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Seignor, you have ſo work't upon me with your generoſity, that I here make a ſolemn proteſtation to become another Man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Twill be the better for you.
Come to my Arms, my much lov'd Frederick. You have preſerv'd me. who is that with you, Anthony?

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: What, my ſervice was taken no notice of. I am ſure you had not been alive but for me. My Arm akes plaguely with hacking and hewing your enemies.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, you make vaſt havock always, when you are half a mile from the Battel.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: I have ever your good word. O my Arm!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Don't your Leggs ake too, Anthony?

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: Nay my Leggs are maul'd too, that's the truth on't, by thruſting in among you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But I mean by the Fetters I found you in but now.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: Fetters, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How the Devil came he in the Stocks to night, Frederick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In the Stocks, you amaze me.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: I in the Stocks! ſure the Danger you have been in has diſtracted you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sure you are both in a Conſpiracy to banter me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Can you be ſerious, Bernardo? prethee no more of this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay, by St. Jago I ſaw him there, fix'd to the Stocks like any Vagabond within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Meer Banter. We are but newly come from the Lodging to ſeek you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why then I have ſeen the Devil to night, that's all. 'Twas one ſo like him in Voice, Perſon, and Raillery after his way, that I am amaz'd to hear you thus deny 'twas He.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sure the Devil doth walk to night, for ſince I came out I have met with much ſuch another accident, which you ſhall hear anon. But prethee what elſe has thy curioſity diſcover'd?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This night has been laviſh of her Adventures, I'll aſſure you, For beſides this Myſtery of Anthony, I have reſcu'd a man from Villains, who, I have reaſon to believe was Don Philip de Monaſco, and he has appointed to meet me this morning near the Great Church. Some other things I have met with too, but they are ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I have a ſecret for your ſecret. This night has indeed been laviſh of her Adventures.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Keep it cloſe, Don Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That you may depend on.
Nothing can Wreſt it from me, but the obligation of being truſted with yours firſt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O Devil, are you thereabouts? but this inſinuation will n'er prevail to extort a ſecret, that I am injoyn'd to keep particularly from thee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! that I muſt own, whetts my curioſity. Prithee, Don Bernardo, come, you ſhall have a ſecret for your ſecret. In good faith, I have one in my keeping.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That you are impatient to get rid of, I thank you, Sir. no, no, hold there. I can be truſted with a ſecret even among the Women. I have not the vanity of moſt young Fellows of the Town, who think the Pleaſure of Telling the principal part of their Happineſs with Ladys.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then 'tis with a Lady, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay that doth not directly follow: But, faith, to be ingenuous with you, there is a Lady in the Caſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then there are two Ladys in the caſe, Boy. And One of ſuch a matchleſs form, ſo Graceful, ſo ſurprizing Fair, ſo infinitely Charming, that as ſhe can have no equal upon Earth, ſo ſhe is above all Human Deſcription.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ha! Where is this Goddeſs to be ſeen? wilt thou not tell me, Frederick? ſhan't your dear friend have a ſight of her?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh, I knew I ſhould be even with you. A Sight of her! You muſt excuſe me, Sir. Goddeſſes are inviſible to Mortal Eyes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, I ſee when once a Man has indulg'd the Humour of bantering, 'tis as hard for him to leave it, as 'tis for a Poet to ceaſe Writing, when he has once begun.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Or as 'tis for you to avoid wiſhing to go to Bed to every Deſcription of a fine Woman that you hear.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, you have ſurpriz'd me. But prithee, put me in Mind, as we Walk, and I'll diſcloſe ſomething to you that was a Secret, but is no longer worthy to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I knew he could not hold.
Come on then, let us Walk.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Firſt give me leave, Frederick, for my Satisfaction, to order your Man Anthony to place himſelf near thoſe Lodgings, to bring me Word if any Man comes out, when it grows Lighter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Heyday, what's to do now!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You ſhall know as we Walk.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This is ſome Jealouſy about a Wench, I'll lay my Life.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: She's a handſome one at leaſt then, and you know Venus is predominant over me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, yes. 'Tis a Superſtition much in faſhion with young Fellows. You will be wiſer, Don Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You ſhall know preſently that I have begun at leaſt already, by throwing off this Woman, near whoſe Lodgings your Man is to watch. And the Wiſe ſay, That a Good Beginning is half a Cure. But come, let us walk homewards. Anthony, be ſure you place your ſelf ſomewhere about that Door, that you may diſcover who comes out this Morning, and bring an exact account home to us.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: I ſhall do my beſt, Sir, to ſatisfy you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Now, let us walk.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come on, my truſty Adventurer.

div.head: Scene I. The Street near Eleonora's.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: WAS there ever ſuch a Cormorant at Whoring as this Don Bernardo? no Place, no Time, nor no Woman almoſt can be free from his Perſecutions. A Pox of theſe Night-doings, and what elſe can be the end of them! Hark, the Door opens.

div.stage: Don Sebaſtian muffled in his Cloak comes out. Eleonora in her Night-gown.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Well, and muſt Nelly part with her dear Don then?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: 'Tis for your Service I go ſo ſoon, my Dear.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: For your own rather.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: You might have ſtay'd with me all day, my Love, for once.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: How unreaſonable a Creature is Woman!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: And tho' I have been nicely careful of my Reputation, yet for your Company I could venture all things.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: A very civil Perſon!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt, my Eleonora, there is no Ingratitude on my ſide. Thou know'ſt the Promiſes I have made thee, and may'ſt rely on the Performance of them. Nor ſhould I now want Intreaties to ſtay with thee, but that I have a Gueſt at home, whoſe Goodneſs, tho' a Friend, I muſt not treſpaſs on too far. Beſides, to leave him any l • nger would not only ſeem like forgetfulneſs, but ill manners.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I hope the Ruffians too have remembred him before this time.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Madam, good morrow. We may be ſeen, if I ſtay longer.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Well, if you muſt go, Don Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Don Sebaſtian, good!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: You are unkind not to underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: What doſt thou mean, Child?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Psha, you can't tell a Woman's meaning, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: What can ſhe drive at?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: You keep me in the Dark, my Dear.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I ſwear I could chide you, you are ſo dull.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: My Angel, thou ſhalt have twenty of them preſently.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: A Pox on them, how they make my Chops Water!

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Nay now you take my Breath away.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Good morrow to my Joy.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Adieu.
But ſtay, I had forgot one thing.
When will you come and ſee poor Nelly again?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: You'l ſend me your Commands.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Well, adieu.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sebaſtian goes croſs the Stage muffled, and meets Anthony paſſing.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: There goes Anthony Don Philip's Man, but I muſt not diſcover my ſelf to him.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p:
Don Sebaſtian, your Servant. Now will I go home and diſcloſe what I have ſeen to Don Bernardo. Let me ſee, their names
are Eleonora and Sebaſtian, and the Scene between them at parting will make Bernardo curſedly jealous, I know. Well, he ſhall have it all, that's certain; who knows but it may cure him of his frenzy? Eſpecially when 'tis improv'd with ſome of my heightning Colours. Et bien, allez Monſieur Antoine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Won't you go and lye down, Madam? you muſt needs want reſt, for 'twas morning when Don Sebaſtian came.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: No, no. I have other things to mind, before I can take any true reſt. Wee'l Sleep hereafter, Dorila, when we have brought our Deſigns about.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How ſtand affairs with him? doth he hold kind?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: In all appearance he doth. The ſame indearments paſs'd between us as uſual, and when he parted, he gave me more aſſurances of his Reſolution to marry me. But ſtill to be in expectation only is not to be ſo eaſie as I could wiſh: I hope Bernardo got off ſafe, for if the Men I hir'd to diſpatch Philip ſhould have miſtaken him in the Dark for the other, there's a part of my Deſign confounded.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Or grant he be come off, your denying to admit him at ſuch a dangerous time may provoke him to think no more of you.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: 'Twas very unlucky that he ſhould call again before you had acquainted me with the buſineſs of the Ring. But ſince ſuch an Accident has happen'd, I confeſs I don't diſapprove of the Stratagem you devis'd to get him away. Well, Dorila, you ſhall be no Loſer by the Ring.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam. We never want invention at a Shift, you know. But how will you do to excuſe your ſelf to him?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I'll go and write to him this minute, and endeavour that way to make him forget the uſage of laſt Night, and if I can but inſinuate my ſelf into his forgiveneſs, and find him ſo much a Lover as I think him, who knows what it may end in?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Articles of Matrimony perchance, if you hold the Fort out well.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I warrant thee, girl. 'Tis not all the Artillery of his Arguments, that can perſwade me to another ſurrender without honourable Terms. I was always averſe to this way of Living, and am now reſov'd to take up with the firſt likely Husband I can get, with Schaſtian, or Bernarde, or any Body elſe, I am indifferent who 'tis, ſo 'tis a Husband. But come, I'll go and Write.

div.head: SCENE Don Frederick's Lodgings. A Bedchamber.
div.stage: Frederick, and Cornelia in Man's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I had not preſum'd to diſturb you, Madam, but that I heard you were ſtirring. This Philip, whom you ought to forger, won't let you Sleep, I find.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You rally me, Sir, perhaps juſtly enough. But alas! when 'tis our Fate, we can no more help. Loving, than we can Dying.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ay, but when a Man abuſes Love, and counterfeits a Paſſion to delude a Woman, methinks the force of Reaſon ſhould make her deſpiſe him after the Diſcovery of the Cheat.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You argue very well, Sir, and according to reaſon: But don't you know that Love and Reaſon are inconſiſtent?
But, Sir, is there any News of him in Valencia? your obliging promiſe makes me hope you have made ſome enquiry after him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Madam, I have: and can inform you that I hope to find him in this Town.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Where, Where? O tell me quickly, that I may fly to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Amazement! That ſo ungrateful a Wretch ſhould be lov'd by ſo beautiful a Creature, whom he has abus'd beyond all patience!

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Don Frederick, my Friend, for I dare call you ſo. Where is this Rambler to be found?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Madam, you honour me very much, but I had rather be thought to deſerve another Name.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: What other Name? are not you call'd Don Frederick? Or is Friend too little for you? I thought it comprehended the utmoſt Eſteem.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Eſteem alone's a trifle, Madam, to that which I would merit. 'Tis your Love, fair Excellence, that I aſpire to raiſe. You have ſo wounded me with your reſiſtleſs Beauty, that nothing but the Poſſeſſion of thoſe Charms that made the miſchief, can effect the Cure.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Sir, I took you to be more generous than to triumph over a diſtreſs'd Maid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: By all that's ſacred I am ſincere. Don Philip may abuſe you, but not Frederick. I have a Heart unpractis'd in Deceit: A Heart that ne'er was tortur'd with the pangs of Love, till now.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I do confeſs I thought you very honeſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I thank my Stars I can boaſt of it. O do not refuſe ſo paſſionate, and yet ſo true a Lover.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I do intreat you, Sir, forbear. You know I am engag'd to one I love.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But to one you ought to loath. A Man that has ſcorn'd and abus'd you.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: And yet I love him, Frederick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The more's the Pity. What can you propoſe by following ſuch a treacherous Fellow?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: To reclaim him, or to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The firſt you'l find impracticable. 'Tis like beſieging a very ſtrong Town with a ſmall Force. You will but expoſe your ſelf to Contempt and Ruine.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Why then I'll be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That you may by indulging my Suit. Come, let it not be ſaid that the heavenly Cornelia was inexorable. Give me but Hopes, and you ſet me in the way to Paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Revenge is ſo ſweet, that upon Condition you let me ſee Philip, and he denies to own me for his Wife, I could almoſt be perſwaded to believe you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I accept the Condition with as much Tranſport of Bliſs, as e're Condemn'd Criminal receiv'd his pardon. Now will I go and ſearch my Doom. Life or Death depends on a few hours. But, Madam, I muſt intreat you to conſent that I may acquaint your Brother with your Circumſtance, that we may be the Stronger for the Execution of our Deſign.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I reſign my ſelf to your Conduct.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I'll wait on you again, when I have prepar'd Don Bernardo.

div.head: SCENE Changes to another Room.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: If I can truſt my Eyes, the more I look the more I am amaz'd. This very Ring, or my Sight is not my own, I gave my Siſter Cornelia, when I departed laſt from Alcamara. That it ſhould be found in Valencia gives me Wonder, but that it ſhould be ſent me from Donna Eleonora pats me into Confuſion. Well, things have been ſtrangely carried to night in Valencia.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Seignor, a Young Gentleman without deſires to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Admit him. This Ring won't out of my Head. When I conſider the Accident by which I obtain'd it, and the ſucceeding one, wherein the ſame Eleonora that ſent it, ſeem'd to know nothing of the matter, I muſt own I can't but fancy 'tis all a Dream.

div.stage: Enter Donna Olivia in Man's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Am I not bold, Sir, to venture within the Roof where an angry Brother might be found, that would kill me if he knew me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You are both ſafe and welcome here.
sp.stage: Runs to the Door and ſhuts it faſt.
sp.p: I have faſten'd the Door, leſt Don Frederick ſhould chance to fall in.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Well, Sir, have you heard any thing of Don Philip, ſince I ſaw you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O, I find I am oblig'd to your Impatience to hear of Him for this Viſit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Good Sir, Torture me not with Supence: If you have not, I am come to claim your Promiſe to aſſiſt me in ſearching after him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sure there is Inchantment in Love, that it can make People thus eager to purſue their Ruine!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Alas! your Reflections are now out of Seaſon. I beſeech you anſwer me to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I am deceiv'd, or I ſav'd his Life laſt Night, when he was encounter'd by Ruffians.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: A thouſand Bleſſings attend you for it. But are you ſure 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By ſeveral Circumſtances I am almoſt aſſur'd. But this Morning at Ten I am to meet the Man I reſcu'd. He would not give me his Name, but deſir'd me to exchange Swords with him, that he might know me again by that. Here's that I had of him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: O, 'tis he. 'Tis Don Philip. 'Tis the very Sword I have ſeen him wear. I know it from a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, ſince 'tis ſo, if you pleaſe, we'll go together to the Great Church, where I have appointed to meet him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: With all my Heart. O lucky Diſcovery!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But one thing will be neceſſary firſt. 'Tis fit Don Frederick ſhould be acquainted with your affairs.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Be it as you pleaſe. I truſt to you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: In the mean time pray uſe my Apartment. You'l ſee no Body to diſturb you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Thanks, Fortune, that this Dear, falſe Man is found.
Oh, how I long to chide him for his Abſence!
Sure when he ſees me thus diſguis'd, thus bold
In my purſuit of him, he will recant
His Sex's Levity, and fix his Soul
On me, on virtuous Love, and mutual Vows.

div.stage: 2 Anthony comes in, and would go through to another Room.
div.p: Ha! either my Eyes deceive me, or there's his Servant Anthony. Hold, Friend, be not in ſuch haſt. Where's thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Seignor, I want to find him.
sp.stage: Cornelia comes in behind from another Room.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What, did you expect to find him in this Houſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt likely to find him at home, for He's no Gadder ab •• ad. I'll aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What, doth Don Philip then lie in this Houſe?

sp.speaker:
2
• nt.
sp.p: No, Sir, who ſaid he did?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why, didſt not thou this moment?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Not I, by St. Jago.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Prithee leave off thy old fooling.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: It ſeems you know me then.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Alas! but too well.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I have not the good Fortune to remember you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: That may very well be. But prithee tell me, how long has Don Philip lodg▪d here?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he doth not lodge here; nor ever did, that I know of; and more than that, Sir, I know no ſuch Perſon. Now, Sir▪ I muſt beg your leave to go through to that Apartment, to ſee if my Maſter be there, that I may diſcharge my Errand.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What▪s the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You ſeem, Sir, to have been mov'd to ſome Surprize about that Fellow. Pray, Who do you take him for?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Have I not Reaſon, Sir, if I'm alive 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Pray, who?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why Don Philip de Monaſ • o's Man.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Do you know that Don Philip, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I have ſome Cauſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Then you know a Villain.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You ſhock me, Sir; for he's my Friend, and I muſt not hear him wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: How long has he been your Friend?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: A great while. He is my Boſom-Friend.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Thoſe Boſom-Friends prove often our worſt Foes.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But I have try'd him.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: He may deeeive you ſtill. If you were a Woman, he wou'd certainly.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Ha! Sure he doth not know me.
Why do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Becauſe he is a Man.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Your Satyr's too extenſive. We are not all falſe.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I fear all.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You have accus'd your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: No, I accus'd the Men.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Are not you one?

sp.speaker: Corn.
