sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir; but I meant ſuch Men as Don Philip. Alas! I had like to have diſcover'd my ſelf.
Sir, I beg you would excuſe me. I am a little thoughtful, and know not what I ſay. If you lodge here, I ſhall be glad of your Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I do but viſit here, Sir. But if you have any Juſtice to demand of Philip, I'll let him know it.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: The World ſhall know it ſoon. This Morning I expect my ſelf to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Pray how long has he he been in Valencia?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: That I know not; but that he is here, I have had ſome Information. Good morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Who can this be? He ſeems to have ſome Reſentment againſt Don Philip, therefore it muſt be my Care to prevent its burſting out into a Flame. I'll enquire about him.

l.hi: Strange Pow'r of Love, that makes us court ev'n Pain,
To flie true Paſſion, and purſue Diſdain.

div.head: Another Room.
div.stage: Enter Don Frederick with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: For Don Bernardio. 'Tis a Woman's Hand by the over-ſpelling.

div.p: Sure no Jeſuit ever confeſs'd more Women, than thou haſt brought to the Altar of Venus. See here

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Oh 'tis from Eleonora. She would excuſe her Behaviour to me laſt-Night. But I deſpiſe her now as much as e're I lov'd her. I hope her Barbarity will make me forget the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A wholſom Reſolution, if you could keep it. I ſuppoſe I may read the Letter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes, and viſit the Lady if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay then you are indifferent indeed.

body.p: I Am ſorry my Circumſtances with my Aunt oblig'd me to uſe you as I did laſt Night, but my Well-being ſo depends upon her Opinion of me, that I am ſometimes forc'd to do things againſt my inclination. I hope this will find you ſafe, and enjoying the ſame good Humour, that has ſo often engag'd my Thoughts in your behalf. Aſſure your ſelf I am impatient to hear of your Welfare, and ſhould not be diſpleas'd to ſee you come in the Afternoon, not ſo much to give me a Relation of the Affair of the Ring, as to convince me that you are well, and inclin'd to forgive the ſeeming fault of

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A Jilt! with what a face ſhe carrys it on! Well, you'l Viſit her in the Afternoon, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No, Frederick, but you ſhall in my Room, if you think good. For my part, her uſage laſt night has ſo provok'd me, that I have not ſo much as Indifference left for her. Beſides, this fawning trick of a Letter perſwades me that ſhe's a Jilt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am glad you are of my mind. That ſhe is ſo, I'll venture the reverſion of my Father's Eſtate. What, don't I know their ſubtle, coy, diſſembling, fond, alluring, falſe Deſigns? Proteus himſelf had fewer Shapes, than one of theſe jilting Whores. They are like Ariſtotle's firſt matter, capable of any Form.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Let her be what ſhe will, I'll ſend her an anſwer, but it ſhall be an honeſter Letter: For I'll tell her in plain Terms 'tis my Inclination to forget her.

div.p: But hold, here's Anthony return'd, whom we left upon the Watch.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what has your Curioſity diſcover'd?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: No miracle, Seignor, for I have ſeen a Fornicator come out of a Whore's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have a care whom you aſperſe, Sirra.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: I hope I may truſt my ſight; but if that alone won't do, I have another ſenſe to back it. I heard as well as ſaw.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well, what was it you heard?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: I heard one Eleonora take her leave of one Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sebaſtian! Are you ſure 'twas ſuch a Name?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p:
I think I am not deaf. And when he was going, ſhe came out with him, and there was ſuch Ceremony at parting, ſuch Unwillingneſs to let him go, ſo many ſoft things, ſuch Kiſſing and ſuch Dying
on her ſide, and ſuch a cold Civility and Backwardneſs to underſtand her on his, that for my part—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You wondred he could leave the Banquet ſo ſoon, and wiſh'd your ſelf in his Place.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: What, when the Soup was pall'd, and had loſt its Guſto. No, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why could not you have had prtience till it had been cook'd up again?

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis ſomewhat a la Francoiſe indeed. But truly I have more Nicety. 'Tis not a mon gout.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Enough, enough; leave us.
What, think you now, my Amoriſt?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That Women are no more to be beleiv'd than Courtiers. They differ only in this, Women deceive us by Nature, Courtiers by Art.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, this impoſition doth not want Art, I'll aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Ay, but I mean Women▪s Inclinations to deceive us are born with them Are they not continually forging Plots to make ſome Traffick or other of us? Sure they are our evil Genius's, for there is ſcarce a falſe Path in Life that we are not led into by their fooliſh Conduct. And yet we follow on, as if they were the Leading-ſtrings of Fate, and we were doom'd in this World to the puniſhment of being miguiſed by the weaker Sex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay, now you are unreaſonably ſevere, but 'tis too much an Extremity to laſt long. This is only the hot Fit of the Ague.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But you know the Cold one ſucceeds it, and that is ſtill a greater Mark of Contempt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Tis granted. But for my part, I can't commend Extreams in any thing. And yet I am grown ſince laſt Night, wilt thou beleive it, my Friend? A moſt paſſionate Lover.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Prithee know thy ſelf a little better.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: All other knowledge but that of the unparalell'd Cornelia, is like the Compariſon of the Stars with the Sun.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You amaze me, what Cornelia. do you mean!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Don Bernardo, prepare your ſelf for ſomething that will furprize you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Speak out. I am ready.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Should you not wonder to find your Siſter in this Place?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Very much, Sir. Pray, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Diſguis'd too in Man's Cloaths, I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Are you diſtracted, Frederick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No, Don Bernardo, unleſs it be with Joy. I have hopes, my Friend if Don Philip prove but falſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Don Philip too! What is all this?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I knew you would be ſurpriz'd. But pray compoſe your ſelf, and I'll diſcloſe a Secret, which 'tis convenient you ſhould know.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Speak it aloud, if it concern my Honour.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It doth indeed. And to let you know it in a Word, Don Philip, whom you ſo lately reſcu'd, once made pretenſions to your Siſter, but they were ſuch as Virtue could not hear, and yet ſhe lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That is, ſhe had a Mind to be undone, but a little of her Sex's Pride ſav'd her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You ſhall hear. He ſoon perceiv'd her ſeeming Weakneſs, and laid his Batteries againſt that part, but bravely ſhe repuls'd him. In ſhort they both engag'd again, till having made Trial of each others Force, they drew off and parred. Some Articles, it ſeems, had been agreed to on both ſides, but he refuſing to perform his part your Siſter grew incens'd, and in diſguiſe purſu'd him to this Place.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You would imply they were contracted, and after he refus'd to marry her, but ſought only to abuſe her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You have it. Yet ſhe loves him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Baſe Villain! but you ſhall do her Juſtice, you ſhall, or by Heav'n I'll root out your perfidious Tongue. Now Ring, your Myſtery is out. An unlick'd Brute, to throw away a Lady's Favour, which any one elſe would have eſteem'd invaluable.
But hold. Don Frederick, you gave me Caution to be prep ar'd to hear what has indeed aſtoniſh'd me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I beleive ſo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Now do you guard your ſelf againſt a worſe Event

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! ſpeak out.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Are you prepar'd againſt ſurprize?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Speak. I defy ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why then the ſame perfidious Dog has whor'd thy Siſter, and forſaken her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have a care, I charge thee. My Siſter, and a Whore by the ſame Don Philip. Sure you want ſleep, Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I wonder not at your Amazement, but ſo it is.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Tis a rank Falſhood. Bernardo, you have ſuggeſted this to abuſe me. Now by the untainted Honour of our Houſe, Olivia muſt be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The Contradiction was unmannerly. But Thou art Angry, and I conſider Raſhneſs is the Birth of Anger, or by the King of Spain I would not bear it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I do confeſs my Fault, and ask your Pardon. But, prithee tell me, What doſt thou mean about Olivia?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That I have met with her to Night in Valencia, and have heard her Story, which acquainted me with his villanous Deſertion after he had obtain'd her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If this be ſo, by all that's Great and Pow'rful, this Day's his Laſt, if he refuſe to Wed her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay there I am for you. But hold, let me ſee! How ſhall I do Juſtice then for Cornelia?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Tis true; Cornelia muſt be righted, tho' Olivia ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Not ſo neither. Let Juſtice have its Courſe. It ſeems, you know her Story.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I do, which you ſhall have anon.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Which done, we'll refer all to Philip at the time of Appointment this Morning; and if he refuſe to marry Her whom it ſhall appear he has moſt wrong'd, he muſt have ſpeedy Puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Agreed; and tho' I love your Siſter moſt paſſionately, if ſhe appears moſt wrong'd, I'll force him to receive her for his Wife, or Die in the Attempt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis generouſly reſolv'd. Tho' for your ſake I wiſh it on Olivia's ſide, that we may be more than Friends, Brothers.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If Providence ſo orders it, I ſhall be ſupreamly bleſs'd on Earth. Such a Wife and ſuch a Brother would ſet me above a Throne.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: We muſt leave all to Fate. But come, I'll go write to this barbarous Eleonora, and then for our meeting with Don Philip at the Church.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

q.l: Now, Love, if for a God thou woud'ſt be known,
And art determin'd to ſupport thy Throne:
Diſplay thy Pow'r, and vindicate thy Fame,
Reward true Love, Revenge thy injur'd Name.

div.head: Scene I. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Don Sebaſtian and Don Philip with a Servant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: ARe you ſure you ſaw him ſo early, and alone?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: 'Twas he, or my Eyes deceiv'd me much. But I am amaz'd to hear how you loſt him; ſure he is diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hang him, to deny me to my Face, and to follow another Maſter without any cauſe of Diſguſt—I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: 'Tis a Riddle indeed beyond my Ability to ſolve.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And beneath your Care. 'Tis but a Fool loſt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I wonder who 'twas came to your aſſiſtance laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Twas then too dark to diſtinguiſh him, but I promis'd to meet him at Ten this Morning near the Great Church. Let me ſee.
'Tis within half an hour on't.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I believe it may.
sp.stage: Dorila croſſes the Stage in haſt, and drops a Letter.
sp.p: Ha! What's that ſhe has dropt?
Methought 'twas Dorila, that went into her Miſtreſs's. For Donna Eleonora. Unſeal'd too, then 'twill be no ill Manners to open it.
Now who art thou from? Bernardo. 'Tis from a Man it ſeems. Let me ſee.
sp.stage: Walks about and Reads to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you'l let me ſhare in the Accident, I hope.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I begg you would excuſe me. It happens to be a Secret wherein I am more than ordinarily concern'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then I am no longer curious.
sp.stage: Sebaſtian Reads as to himſelf in a low Voice.

body.p: WHat Satisfaction ſoever you could take in not ſhelt'ring me laſt Night from almoſt inevitable Deſtruction: Yet know, Cruel. Woman, that I have eſcap'd, nay doubly eſcap'd both from the Villains you your ſelf employ'd for Murder, and from the Sanres of a Deſigning and perfidrous Jili. Neither am I ignorant who it was that hindred my admittance; and to give you a juſt Correction for your Treachery, I ſhall find a Way to let Don Sebaſtian know how falſe you are to him. Alas! Your invitations have now loſt their Force. I deſpiſe you and your Letters. Your trifling Preſent too, which is not worth returning. And to finiſh your mortification, know, that the Inclinations I had for you are turn'd into Revenge,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Now I have a very fair occaſion to get rid of an old Miſtreſs, that I have long ſuſpected to play me falſe. This Letter is convincing▪ The Obligation I was under of my promiſe to marry her, join'd with the Charms I ſtill found in her, kept me to my uſual Complaiſance, and Heaven knows how far two ſuch pow'rful Advocates as Honour and Beauty might have prevail'd but for this fortunate Accident. Marry her! Forbid it all ye Powers. Now by St. Jago, I'd ſooner Wed Infection. Hateful Eleonora! I'll go to her this Moment, and declare my Reſolution
sp.stage: [All this in a low Voice to avoid being heard by Philip.]
sp.p: My dear Friend, I begg your Excuſe. I have found ſomwhat of much Import to me, that requires my immediate abſence for a few Moments. I'll meet you near the Church forthwith; do you wait upon Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Some Amour of his at bottom, I'll lay my Life. This Love is as infectious as the Plague, and diffuſes it ſelf as haſtily, but is not quite ſo mortal, Heav'n be prais'd. Whatever Darts and Flames ſome People find in it, I thank my Stars I am yet Heart-whole
Languiſhing and Dying for a Woman's Toy is ſuch a Jeſt with all my Heatt. Sir, pray ſing the Song I ſo much admire.

l.hi: BEauty is not what I pray,

lg.l: Celia has another way,

l.hi: Kind Heav'n, it is enough for me.
Fruit, that doth ſo quickly Cloy,
No true Bliſs in Love we find,
Unleſs two Bodies ſhare one Mind.

sp.p: Here's ſomething for your Trouble. Now towards the Church.

div.stage: Eleonora's Lodgings. Don Sebaſtian and Dorila.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Dorila, where's your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: She's in her Chamber, Seignor.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Let her know I am here.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir, and ſhe'll be o'erjoy'd to ſee you here again ſo ſoon.
I don't like this ſudden return tho'. I wiſh it doth not preſage ſome extraordinary event.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Her Joy will be ſoon abated, when ſhe ſees me depart again ſo ſoon, at leaſt upon ſuch an Occaſion. Now muſt I reſolve to be Flint, or ſhe with her damn'd, alluring, female Wiles will melt me to forgiveneſs. But— I have thought on a Way to countermine her.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: O my Dear Sebaſtian.
This is unexpectedly kind to return ſo ſoon. Beleive me, I am ſo full of Joy, I want Words to expreſs it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Avaunt, thou fawning Strumpet. Thou Spirit of Deluſion. See here this Letter. Have I not foſter'd thee in my Boſom moſt tenderly, and Thou, like an ungrateful Viper, haſt ſet thy Teeth againſt thy Preſerver?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: You are ſoon offended, Seignor, at nothing. 'Tis true, I did receive this Letter. But pray, Sir, how am I to blame if Men will be ſo impertinent as to write to me. Beſides, you ſee he confeſſes that I us'd him ill.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Yes, you have your Arts to ſhew your ſeeming Frowns ſometimes, to provoke Men to ſtudy how to reconcile you. This is your Sex's Method to draw us on to our Ruine. Go, you are perfidious, and remember 'twas your own inconſtancy not mine, that caus'd our Separation.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Shall it then be ſaid that Don Sebaſtian did but ſeem to be a Man of Honour, and good Nature, not eaſily poſſeſs'd with Fancies, ſlow of Belief, a Lover of his Friend, ſoon provok'd, but ſoon returning to himſelf? you ſee, this is the trick of a malicious Fellow to ruine me. For that's the Conſequence, when my Sebaſtian thinks me falſe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: So. This I expected.
Madam, You need not be ſo much concern'd. The World is wide enough, and Fools are plenty.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: What, will you go without hearing me? The vileſt Criminal is allow'd his Defence. I am not guilty, do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: No, that's playing at hazard. Why ſhould I attempt to throw again, when I have nick'd you already? Farewel.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: and Dorila hold him.] Do but hear us, let us both intreat you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: You are both as falſe as Hell.
So. Farewel. I▪ll never fee you more.

sp.speaker: El
sp.p: Devil, you are the cauſe of all this. Now may I go and hang my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am as much concern'd, Madam, as 'tis poſſible. You can't believe I dropt the Letter on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: How do I know but you did! I believe you and Bernardo are in a Conſpiracy to undo me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You reward me liberally for all my Services. I thought I had given you ſufficient Proofs of my Fidelity.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: How couldſt thou drop that Letter ſo unhappily? Or what had you to do to meddle with it?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I thought I had taken more than ordinary Care of it; for I put it into my Boſom when I went to make Enquiry after the Ruffians, and how I dropt it by the way, or where, I can't imagine.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: A greater Misfortune ſure could not have happen'd to me: For now my Expectations are all croſs'd, my ſpringing Hopes are blaſted in the Bud, and nought remains but wither'd Diſappointment, and a fruitleſs Waſt of Deſpair.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Have Patience, Madam, they have but ſerv'd you like Men, which may be a Warning to you hereafter not to truſt any of the Sex.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Truſted! No; they ſhall be deſpis'd by me for ever. Certainly there is not in the Creation ſo vile a Monſter as Man, and yet we Women are ſuch Fools to liken him to an Angel.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: That's before we know him. As ſoon as Curioſity has brought us acquainted with him, we ſee the Devil lurking under that Angel's Form.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: O that I could recover my ſtoln Honour, and thoſe Golden days of innocence which I enjoy'd, but knew not how to prize, before I liſten'd to falſe Man. Curſe upon the Sex, they are all diſſembling Villains, Curſe on my Ears for hearkning to their Arguments, and doubly curs'd be my Credulity for truſting them beyond the bounds of Vertue.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Reſtrain your paſſion, Madam.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Yes, I will, you ſhall ſee I will.

Truſt them no more, forget them, there lies your happineſs. Ha! But how forget them to be happy. I have it. I thank you, friendly Powers, that have ſo ſoon ſpread forth your Providence. I'll turn Nun, and ſpend the remainder of my Days in penitence for my paſt Offences.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Are you in your Wits? good Venus, how you talk?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Somewhat diſagreeably to your Taſt, it ſeems. But, know, I am determin'd, and moſt fortunately this very Day is the great Feſtival of St. Jago, a proper Day to enter into my year of Probation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why then you are another Magdalen. But truly if I might adviſe you, you are now in the Flower of your Age, and may propoſe to ſpend many a happy Year in the enjoyment of the World: Why ſhould you ſeek Death, when Life is yet ſo well worth preſerving?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Thou art deceiv'd in Life. What is it but a Succeſſion of Troubles? A meer Quotidian Ague, which by the conſtant ſupply of Hopes and Fears, knows little intermiſſion as long as Nature laſts.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Uſe your Pleaſure, Madam. I thank my Stars, I am not yet weary of the World.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: However, let us retire together, that I may take my laſt leave of you, when I am prepar'd for my Heavenly Journey.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll wait on you, Madam, to the Threſhold of Death, but you muſt excuſe me from going over it.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I wiſh your happineſs, but can't compell it.

div.head: SCENE the Street, near the great Church.
div.stage: Enter Conſtable and Watch, with 1 Anthony; Don Philip meets them.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat:
sp.p: Come, this way with him. This way leads to Don Sebaſtian's

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.p: Hold, Friends, don't be ſo very haſty, d'ye ſee. Pray, let us conſider a little, dy'e mind me, what we ſhall ſay to the Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: Why, that's very true, Neighbour. We ought to lay our ſtory well, d'ye ſee me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My Man Anthony, as I live! How the Devil came he among that fry of Leaches? But 'tis what he deſerves: Yet I'll ask them, to amuſe my ſelf, till Don Sebaſtian's return.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Enough, enough; come away with him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hold, Gentlemen. Pray, whither are you conducting that Fellow?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: But that you promiſe for a Perſon of Note, we ſhould not have time to anſwer any Man's queſtions: We are carrying him to Don Sebaſtian's to be committed for a Houſe-breaker.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: O Sir, I'm glad I have found you again. I have been baited, Sir, no Tyger was ever ſo baited, as I have been by theſe Spaniſh Dogs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You are come in good time, Seignior, to do a peice of juſtice

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mr. Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Matter, Seignior? An pleaſe your Worſhip, we have brought a Stranger here, that we found hid to Night in a Cellar Window, juſt ready to ſet the City a Fire about our Ears, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Is not this your Man, Don Philip?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If I have Eyes 'tis he, pray examine him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: How now, Anthony? How come you under the guard of the Conſtable and the Watch?

sp.speaker: 1 Am.
sp.p: Your Worſhip knows as well as I. One thing I know, which is, that I have been abus'd moſt diſgracefully.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis no more than you deſerve, ungrateful Villain! Did you not forſake me laſt Night when I was aſſaulted in the Street, and did I not meet you afterwards following another Maſter? And more than that, when I claim'd you for my Servant, did you not utterly diſown that you knew me, or had ever ſeen me before.

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Sure, this is but a Dream, Sir: For this Life-guard of mine here, (Pox choak them) can anſwer to my diſgrace, that I have ſat in the Stocks all Night.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: That he has indeed, I'll witneſs it, for he was put in by my order.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hey-day! Sure I Dream ſtill, or I'll be ſworn I met him Early to Day.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: He was ſafe lockt down from one a Clock till within this half hour, I'll paſs my Word.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Nay now I can diſprove you; for if I have Eyes, I ſaw him paſs by me very early to Day.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: An'pleaſe your Worſhip, what the Watchman ſaid muſt needs be true, for he ſtood near him all the time till he was releas'd

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Then will I be Sacrific'd: Go, you are all a pack of Raſcals, Releaſe him, I'll anſwer for him.

div.stage: Enter Don Bernardo and Don Frederick with Cornelia and Olivia in Mens Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: There's Don Sebaſtian, and he with him ſhould be Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Bernardo, 'twere fit they withdraw a while, till we have prepar'd him for the Interview.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By all means. Ladies, will you oblige us by retiring a ſtep or two, till we have had ſome conference with thoſe Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Another Woman diſguis'd?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We will.

div.stage: Bern. and Fred. walk by them and view them.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.p: Sir, by that Sword you wear, I ſhould be much your Debtor, ſure you releiv'd me laſt Night, when I was aſſaulted by Villains.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I did indeed attempt a Gentleman's relief laſt Night, who exchang'd Swords with me, and 'tis very likely you are he.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The ſame. And believe, Sir, that as I am bound to you for my preſervation, ſo ſhall I be always ready to ſerve you with my Life.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Serve your ſelf firſt, Don Philip, and be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! what means this odd, familiar Counſel?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Have you not abus'd Cornelia, my Siſter? Now if thou art a Man, ſpeak truth.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Olivia's wrong'd too, Philip, think of that, and know her Brother's here to do her juſtice.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You have ſomewhat ſurpriz'd me, Gentlemen, with your accuſations.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you deny the facts?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What if I do?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then we muſt try the cauſe this way, Draw,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You may be ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Hold, Gentlemen, Don Philip is my Friend, and I muſt take his part.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: With all my Heart. We are two and two.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come on thou Poiſon to our Families

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Nay then at you, Sir.

div.stage: They tilt Phil. diſarms Fred. and Bern. Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I hope You're ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But not I, Sir, I have the ſame advantage o'er your Friend, and you have vvrong'd my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Take Your ſatisfaction too, whilſt my Sword holds, it ſhall deny none that ask it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Your fortune is Superior, whatever your Juſtice be.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You owe me both your Lives. And now what I have to beg of you is, that you would ſtifle your Reſentments: And if you'l favour me with your company's to Don Sebaſtian's, I here give you my Honour to do you Juſtice too, as far as in me lies before we part.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay now you'r truly brave.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! What art thou, that in the very ſhape of Anthony, com'ſt hither to perplex us!

sp.speaker: 2 Ant
sp.p: Why I think my Name is Anthony, by the ſingular favour of chance both Frenchman and Spaniard, that is to ſay, a mixture of all the Contrarieties in Nature.

div.stage: The company ſtaring firſt at one, then at the other.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: His very Voice, Perſon, and Raillery.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The Seal and the Print are not more perfectly alike.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis ſomething marvellous, I muſt own: if this ſhould prove my own Apparition now, which they ſay People often ſee a little before their Death, how many Sins haſt thou to anſwer for, pauvre Antoine! What art thou that here uſurp'ſt my Name and Shape?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: O Gentlemen. ſhield me, ſhield me from this Fiend,—'tis certainly—the Devil, he could n'er be ſo like me elſe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This is ſurprizing. From hence came the miſtakes of laſt Night, Don Frederick.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And ours, Don Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: If 'twere not for one curſed Objection, that is not to be got over without a Miracle, I could-ſoon reſolve this Riddle.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Try what you can do.

sp.speaker: 2. Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible Seignior, for the Man I ſhould take him for was drown'd many Years ago.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Examine him however.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Pray, Monſieur Antoine, are you a native of Caen in Normandy?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: Yes,— indeed, Seignior Devil.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: The Devil you are. Was not Monſieur your Father call'd Pierre le Menetrier, that is to be underſtood, Peter the Fidler?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: He was indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Ha! Sure I Dream.
What will this come to? Did not you follow his Trade after his Death?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: I commenc'd Joüeur de Violon that Year the great Turn in England happen'd in 88.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Impoſſible! Thou art ſome Magician, and art reſolv'd to deceive me into madneſs.—One thing more. We •• not you preſs'd abord Monſieur Tourville with a Twin-Brother, that was ſo perfectly your likeneſs, that you were the Amazement of all that ſaw you?

sp.speaker: 1 Ant.
sp.p: I was, and ſhould have taken you for him but that he was blown up in one of thoſe Twenty Ships that were Burnt by the Engliſh, after the Sea-Fight between the French and the Engliſh Fleets.

sp.speaker: 2 Ant.
sp.p: Then art thou my Brother, Anthony? How I was preſerv'd and where, after my misfortune you ſhall know another time.

sp.speaker: 1. Ant.
sp.p: My Brother reſtor'd from the Dead! This is ſuch exceſs of joy to me. Come to my Arms, I will embrace thee, as I would a Woman.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: So let them embrace. Now the Myſtery is over, and you have your Mares again.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Tho' they are Brothers, ſo exact a likeneſs was ſurely never ſeen.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange. But come, let us walk. Don Bernardo; we forget our Friends hard by.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: With Don Philip's and this Gentleman's leave well' call for them, and take them with us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Your Friends too are welcome, Gentlemen, to ſuch poor entertainment as my Houſe can afford.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are very obliging.

div.head: SCENE Shifts.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I ſcorn to deny my ſelf upon ſuch an occaſion. I own I am a Woman, and Married to Don Philip before Heav'n, tho' he has left me: Yet will I purſue him, till I have either found the faithleſs wanderer, or ſpent my Days in the vain Search.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You will, you ſay. Alas! I pity thee, for Thy ſearch will be vain indeed. Know, fond Woman, that he's mine by legal contract, not to be revok'd but by mutal conſent: So much he's mine, that I'll not ſpare him a look to throw away upon thee.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Impotent Avarice! I pitty thee, undone as thou art, as well as deſerted; for he is mine by yet a ſtronger tye than any contract

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: It's falſe: He never was, nor ſhall be. If thou doſt offer any farther claim, thy Life's in danger.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I Laugh at thy rage, unthinking Creature, and to let you ſee how much I value Philip, I here renounce the weakneſs of my Sex, and dare you to the combat for his Love.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Now by great Hymen's Torch, 'twas nobly offer'd, and tho' a Rival ſpoke it, I applaud it.
Come on. Now for Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: She who ſurvives is happy.

div.stage: Don. Philip, Frederick, Sebaſtian, and Bernardo come in, followed by the Anthony's

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! at Wars? What new adventure's this? We left you but now unaccquainted with each other, as we thought.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: And are return'd too ſoon. You have hindered the effect of a noble contention. Don Philip there! Then am I ſatisfy'd, for ſure he'l do me juſtice.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Ha! Do I ſee my Love again? But hold, fond Heart, keep up thy uſual Pride, leaſt the falſe wretch inſult and ſcorn thy weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, I am yet a ſtranger to you: How can I do you juſtice?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis but acknowledging Olivia for your Wife.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Olivia her ſelf. This is beyond my hopes. I will acknowledge thee, thou Miracle of Love.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Villain, hold. See Cornelia too, diſguis'd as ſhe is. See your contracted Wife.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: What, doth he demur upon it?
Die then, ungrateful wretch.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Stop thy mad Hand, or ſheath thy Blade within this Breaſt, ſo it may ſave Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My dear Olivia, I Bluſh to ſee this kindneſs from thee.
Madam, you might have been leſs outragious. I muſt own I have been to blame, but am now reſolv'd—

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: To marry Olivia, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I was a going to ſay Madam—

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: That thou art perjur'd. Enough, thou haſt my conſent to be ſo. Be thy Perjury thy Puniſhment: For my part I freely diſcharge thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to your Paſſion then, for it has made you conſent to clear me of ſuch an imputation. You have revok'd your contract, and ſo do I before theſe witneſſes. Donna Olivia, here is my Hand, take it, and my Heart along with it, I doubt not but this Action will reſtore me to my true happineſs. Gentlemen, I hope you own my juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I cannot deny your obligation here to be ſuperiour.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: This fortunate Event tranſports me beyond expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May I preſume, Madam, to remind you of your late conditions?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Are you not a Man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Madam.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: How then are you to be truſted? The only one I ever yet confided in has deceiv'd me. But [ſighing] you have my promiſe, e'en diſpoſe of me as you will

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Madam, you have made me intirely happy. You have not only bleſs'd me with your ſelf, but made a worthy Friend my Brother.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But hold, one thing more. Cornelia, do you know this Ring?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Yes, ſure. 'Twas your gift, which I could have parted with to no one, but Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I know it too and Bluſh. But how came you by it?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Think where you diſpos'd of it, then ask no more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I was mad when I parted with it, but I find where you have been.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I fell in my accident, as you ſhall know another time. In the mean while we are all ſatisfied. Joy to you all. I could almoſt wiſh my ſelf in the ſame condition, but not with Eleonora, Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You once wiſh'd it with her, Don Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Eleonora, and Bernardo! This muſt be he who writ that Letter.
Sir, I believe we are both deliver'd from the ſame perfidious Woman. Did not you write lately to one Eleonora?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I dare confeſs it. She us'd me ill, and I let her know it. Poſſibly your underſtanding with her brought you to know it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: That ſhe has been of my acquaintance, I don't diſown: But 'twas pure accident made me ſee the Letter. It ſerv'd to confirm me in what I before ſuſpected, and I have ſince broke of all correſpondence with her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I am glad on't, for ſhe is a very Jilt. But what had Don Philip done to her, that ſhe ſhould hire Ruffians to Murder him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Was it ſhe then that ſet thoſe Villains on to Murder me, when I was ſo ſeaſonably releiv'd by you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: So I afterwards diſcover'd by one of the ſame Ruffians, whom I had wounded and ſeized, after they had attack'd me by miſtake of the Sword you gave me at parting, and it ſeems Eleonora had hired them for a hundred Crowns to Murder you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What a She-Devil is this! I knew her formerly at Madrid, a Woman of a light Character, who would fain have perſwaded me to marry her. When ſhe could not prevail, ſhe remov'd from thence hither as I had been inform'd. Wherefore when I came to this Town, I recollected what I had heard, and enquiring her out, I laſt Night made a viſit to her, and it ſeems by the ſtory, when I went from her, ſhe ſent Villains after me to diſpatch me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: What, did ſhe entertain You too?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O, ſhe was my old acquaintance, and I ſuppoſe would have been reveng'd on me for the ſlight I had put upon her.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: What a rare Wife I ſhould have had! Fortune thou deſerv'ſt all things from me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well ſhe is going to be reveng'd upon you all. For I was told but now, that ſhe is reſolv'd to leave the ſeducing World, and end her Days in a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That would be ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But the beſt Action of her Life.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, to a Nunnery let her go. In the mean time let Us think a little of this World, and ſince you are all agreed, let the Ladies retire, and ſhift themſelves into their own habits, and wee'l ſee you joyn'd together, before Noon is paſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With all my Soul. Come, my Cornelia, haſt to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Be it as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Tho' Marriage is accounted by ſome a kind of ſervitude, yet I hope, my Olivia, we ſhall have no repenting before the Year is out at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I ſhall make it my endeavour to give no cauſe on my ſide.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come on then, let us haſten to the Trial: One pleaſure at leaſt I am before hand ſure of, and that is in the thought of making ſatisfaction for the wrong I have done.

q.l: For whatſoe'er delight Bad Men can find
In doing wrong, 'tis the unblemiſh'd mind,
That makes our Lives moſt ſweet, our Pleaſures moſt refin'd.
